description:
Matiu Te Huki Haka for life workshop - Moera Hall - Lower Hutt, Matiu Te Huki Haka for life workshop - Moera Hall - Lower Hutt
Haka for Life Workshop� Haka for life – A Transformational Māori Experience with Matiu �Step into a sacred, immersive journey led by Matiu—a master of Māori language, performance, and storytelling, with over 30 years of experience empowering individuals across the globe.This dynamic, interactive workshop weaves together ancient Māori wisdom with modern empowerment, unlocking deep connection, strength, and presence like never before.� What You’ll Experience:� The Warrior’s Energy – Harness the raw power of haka, the traditional Māori dance that awakens your inner fire and unshakable presence.�� The Art of Connection – Learn the profound practice of hongi, the sacred sharing of breath, and cultivate deeper relationships.�� The Power of Storytelling & Song – Discover the soul-stirring magic of Māori narrative and music.�� Sacred Masculine & Feminine Balance – Explore potent, healing practices that honor, empower, and connect on a deep, transformative level.�� Embracing Light & Shadow – Find balance between your strength and vulnerability, your power and grace.� Why This Workshop?This is for those who are ready to step into their power. Those who want to speak with confidence, move with purpose, and lead with authenticity.By the end of this experience, you will:�� Feel grounded, present, and connected—to yourself, to spirit, to your ancestors.�� Command a room with presence and mana (power) when you speak.�� Own your voice—so that people truly listen and feel your words.�� Stand in your warrior energy—unshakable, confident, and fully embodied.�� Walk away with practical, ancient tools to help you move through life with more strength, clarity, and purpose.� Are You Ready? �If you’re up for real growth, if you’re ready to step into your power, be seen, be heard, and be fully present—then this workshop is for YOU.Matiu’s approach is welcoming, inspiring, fun, safe and deeply empowering.� Join us. Awaken your warrior. Change your life.



Here are testimonials for workshop:Kia Ora. I felt new strength to be in integrity with myself and power to speak from this place within. The workshop was a beautiful experience of the love and trust that is possible in community - andthat resonated for ages and flowed into all my interactions moving through life. When are you coming back to Hobart, Matiu, to do more workshops?Here is another testimonial from Bali spirit fest participant:It's not often in life, that I've met someone so powerfully walking their talk, that by their presence alone they can offer a deep transformational experience. I have felt this on both the occasions I've had the pleasure to cross Matiu's path. He has an ability to hold space and guide an opening and understanding of the moment, and the current times. Of divine male/female divide, and the healing available to individuals and our collective. I would highly recommend engaging with him on any level, it's definitely been a rewarding and growth promoting experience in my journey.

description:

👉#MSExcel Intermediate+ Workshop - Blenheim - Thursday 09 October 2025, 9am to 2:30pm - Rangitane House, Level 4.

Includes Lunch, refreshments and a PDF shortcuts

📢Do you want to learn the true capabilities of what Microsoft Excel can do?
📢Do you want to be better and more confident at using Excel?
📢Would you like to learn how to complete tedious tasks more efficiently?

PRE-REQUISITE: We don’t start at the beginner's level, therefore; you must already be a an advanced beginner to intermediate user of Microsoft Excel. If you are not, we also offer an Excel Absolute Beginner workshop and a Beginners to Intermediate workshop.

Our 5.5 hour workshop has been designed for current users of Excel that want to learn more of the intermediate + functions of Excel. You will learn everything you need to know to create small to large spreadsheets within your business, including working with multi sheets, formatting, formulas, functions, diagrams, graphs etc. We will give you the confidence to quickly create any spreadsheet you will require in business.

Our workshop is delivered in Microsoft Office 365 - compatible with Office 2010 upwards (please note that there may be minor differences). Mac is not compatible.

You will need to bring your own device (with Office 2010 upwards). If you are unable to bring your own device, please let us know prior to the workshop and we will arrange one for you.

description:
Mosaic Design, Discover the delights of mosaic design and learn how to use materials such as broken tiles, china, and shells to make a mosaic frame, pot plant holder, or other simple objects.

You'll be able to make several pieces of mosaic to your own design and after the completion of the course, will feel confident to carry on working on your own projects.

A list of materials and tools required (approximate cost $65) will be sent out when course numbers are confirmed. Please wear clothing and footwear suitable for a workshop environment.

By the end of the course, you'll be able to:

Demonstrate the basic principles/techniques of mosaic design

Break and cut tiles correctly

Place tiles on the object

Stick pieces to flat and curved surfaces

Grout a mosaic piece

Use stones and shells in mosaics

description:
NZ Sign Language - Introductory Level 1A, For beginners who have no prior knowledge of NZ Sign Language. Discounted fee of $109 for NZ citizens and residents - ID required.

Description
By the end of the course, you'll be able to communicate in basic sign language and will be able to:

- Introduce yourself, greet other people and exchange personal information
- Demonstrate strategies for: getting attention, asking for clarification, correction and repetition
- Demonstrate the finger spelling alphabet
- Use numbers (0 – 20) and simple time phrases
- Express basic needs and wants
- Use a basic signing vocabulary

description:
Natural Textured Rings, Make your own personalised ring - a gift for yourself or someone special! :-)

Learn the basic technique first in copper or brass, and then craft your final piece in silver!

Over this taster class, you’ll be guided through the process of heating and texturing metal, cutting and shaping with traditional jewellery tools. Use feathers, leaves, or fabrics to create a unique texture for a beautiful ring!

Learn to measure your finger, cut metal to length and texture it without rolling mill, hammers and punches. Then use a jewellers torch, sandpaper and polishing, and your beautiful new ring will be ready to wear.

This 3-hour class is ideal for beginners, groups of friends and visitors to the city.

Included in the class fee are copper and brass for practising on, a sterling silver ring strip and all consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals. Extra metals are available for purchase in the studio.

Kids aged 12 (or so) are welcome to attend the class, but any person under the age of 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.

description:
One Day with Footnote - Workshop, One Day with Footnote is a full day dance workshop tailored for youth and young dancers aged 13-18. This event promises participants an immersive experience into the world of contemporary dance, offering a unique opportunity to learn from seasoned professionals in a supportive environment.
Experience Creativity and Energy: Participants can expect to be swept up in the boundless creativity and infectious energy of the Footnote company dancers. Through a series of dynamic workshops, attendees will explore current creative practices and performance techniques that are shaping the landscape of contemporary dance today. From innovative choreography to expressive movement, this workshop is designed to inspire and challenge young dancers of all levels.

SCHEDULE
9.30-11am Floor work & contemporary improvisation
Discover new pathways to smooth out your floor work and dive into the exciting world of improvisation.
11.30-12.30pm Company Repertoire
Learn current company repertoire and experience the performative and physical range of Footnote shows
1.30-2.15pm Performance Practice
Fine tune your performance skills and learn how to connect with the audience
2.30-3.30pm Choreographic Practice
Explore different creative tasks and gain confidence when creating new movement through guided provocations.
4.30pm Open Studio Sharing + Q&A
Friends and family are welcome to pop in and see what we have been up to!

description:
PADI Open Water Diver Course, PADI Open Water Diver Course
“Ever Since I Was A Kid I’ve Wanted To Learn To SCUBA Dive…”

PADI is by far the largest and most popular Scuba diver certifying system in the world and for good reason. Courses are fun safe relevant and packed with excitement! No matter what country you are in your PADI qualification will be recognised.

To learn to dive first complete the medical questionnaire to make sure you are medically fit to dive. Next pay your deposit and select your course dates. You will receive your PADI eLearning theory which must be completed before you attend the first practical session. This simple and fun eLearning program will give you the knowledge you need to understand the reason for the skills you will learn.

The practical part of your Open Water Scuba Diver course takes just four days! During the first weekend we make it very easy and convenient for you with our on-site dive pool (the only one in the Wellington Region). Our pool is where you learn to dive so we can go at your pace no matter how long it takes. During the first weekend you learn and practice all the necessary dive skills. Once completed you will be ready for the sea dives.

During the second weekend you complete four sea dives two per day. This is where we confirm and practice the skills you learnt in our pool – all under direct supervision. You will also complete a simple 300m swim (no time limit and wearing wetsuit mask snorkel and fins).

Once you are a certified diver you will receive an eCard on your PADI App showing your qualification – and any PADI Dive Centre will be able to confirm your certification online. You will also be qualified to attend the PADI Advanced Open Water Diver course and our regular Dive Days.
Our aim is to prepare you for the fascinating adventure of diving. We want to make your diving safe and enjoyable. Welcome to the exciting world of Scuba diving!

If you have any questions please call email or stop by our Dive Store.
 
PPADI Open Water Diver course at a glance
Digital theory: Open Water Diver eLearning Course (allow 8-14 hours)
Practical: One weekend pool training one weekend with four sea dives
Options: One-on-one or unscheduled dates – additional costs apply.
Start Time: Be at NZ Sea Adventures by 8.30am each day.

Location
We are located at 9 Marina View Mana Porirua; just north of the Paremata bridge on SH1. Look for the big yellow building. Our Location

Prerequisites
Be at least 10 years old (special conditions apply for 10 and 11-year-olds)
Be able to swim 300m (mask snorkel and fins no time limit) and swim/float for 10 minutes.
Be medically fit to dive. Check the Diver Medical Participant Questionnaire. If you answer YES to any of the questions or have any doubts a visit to your doctor is required.
eLearning must be completed before your pool training can begin.
Complete the Optional RDP Tables Quiz and Exam after the final exam if you don’t have a dive computer.

What to Bring
Completed Diver Medical Participant Questionnaire.
If Under 18 years – bring a Parent or Legal Guardian to sign your forms.
A pen swimming costume towel and a snack for the breaks.
Any personal dive equipment you wish to use.
The $450.00 balance of your course fee.

Cost
Scheduled Open Water Diver Course Fee: total is $750.00; deposit is $300.00.
Includes: PADI eLearning Course Dive Gear Rental Pool Sessions and Sea Dives. Rental wetsuits are available in stock sizes only. Other sizes are available for purchase. Made-to-measure options can be ordered and purchased.
10% off all in-store purchases during your course. Does not include packages.
$20 off your course fee for every person you get to sign on with you.

When
Our PADI Open Water Diver Courses are scheduled year-round. See our online calendar for scheduled course dates or ask in store. Booking early guarantees your place and price.

Looking for different dates or smaller classes? Ask about our one-off course options. Let us know what you need and we will do our best to help (conditions may apply).

Booking your course
Course bookings can be made in-store via email online or over the phone
The deposit of $300.00 secures your place on a course and purchases your eLearning course.
Deposits are transferable to another person but are not refundable.
eLearning courses once redeemed cannot be transferred.
Before we can send you the eLearning link we require your full name date of birth a valid personal email address and phone number.
Your course balance is to be paid before we can begin your pool training.

Activities For Certified PADI Open Water Divers
Local Diving; It’s a good idea to keep diving regularly especially in the weeks following your course. We’re here to help with advice on dive sites and gear rental. Want a guide? Join us for Dive Days!
Advanced Open Water course; Further your dive skills and continue your underwater adventures with the PADI Advanced Open Water course you can start straight after your Open Water Diver course.
As a certified PADI Open Water Diver you can take the following Specialty Diver courses alongside those available to non-divers; Altitude Diver – AWARE Fish ID diver – Boat Diver – Digital Underwater Photographer – Diver Propulsion Vehicle Diver – Drift Diver – Drysuit Diver – Enriched Air/Nitrox Diver – Equipment Specialist – Night Diver – Peak Performance Buoyancy – Sidemount Diver – Underwater Naturalist – Underwater Navigation


You may also like the following events from Staff Nzsa:
Next month, 11th October, 08:30 am, PADI Open Water Diver Course in Porirua
Next month, 25th October, 08:03 am, PADI Advanced Open Water Course in Wellington
Also check out other Sports events in Porirua, Workshops in Porirua, Trips & Adventurous Activities in Porirua.

ALL WELCOME! Join us for "Plant and Learn" in the WELLfed Garden

Join the WELLfed Garden crew each Wednesday morning to spend some time gardening and learning!

No experience or skills are necessary - our awesome team can teach you about when and how garden tasks need doing and lots of skills you can use in your own garden.

Garden tasks include composting, seed starting, seed sowing, plant health, biology first gardening (working with nature).
Sharing morning tea (delicious WELLfed snacks provided!) is also a great chance to connect with other awesome humans in our community.

Pre-schoolers are welcome during term time and during the school holidays you are welcome to bring school-aged kids. They can get stuck in and connect with Papatunuku as well, or there is space for outdoor play. Children must be supervised by their caregivers whilst onsite.

Plant and Learn session are weather and staffing dependent - we will post in the event if we won't be gardening due to rain or sickness.

description:
Polish Folk Dance Workshops, We’re thrilled to welcome Maciej Wilczyński to Wellington this September! Maciej is a renowned dancer, choreographer, and cultural ambassador for Polish folk traditions.
Currently collaborating with Poland’s National Song and Dance Ensemble “Silesia” through the Zatańcz z Nami project, he has created over 50 stage arrangements and conducted more than 40 dance workshops across Europe, North America, and Asia.
In 2022, he received the prestigious Creative Scholarship of the City of Kraków for his contributions to folk culture.
Workshop Focus: The dances and traditions of the Cieszyn region
Maciej will lead two sessions tailored for different age groups:
 Workshop 1 - 4:30pm – 6:00pm
Children aged 5–10 years

description:
Spring Container Planting Workshop, Grow Your Own Kai - In Containers From Your Own Compost
Want to grow your own fresh kai but only have a balcony, patio, or courtyard? This hands-on workshop will show you how to grow spring vegetables and herbs in containers - a flexible, low-cost way to turn even the smallest space into a productive garden. Following on from our winter edition, this is the second workshop in our seasonal container growing series, with a focus on getting your spring garden thriving using your own compost.
This workshop will cover:
- What to grow in spring, including leafy greens, herbs, and root vegetables
- How to set up containers - choosing the right size, drainage, potting mix, and using your own compost or bokashi soil
- Feeding your plants with DIY fertilisers, spotting nutrient gaps, and refreshing tired soil
- Creating ideal growing conditions with sunlight, watering tips, wind protection, and natural pest control
- Keeping your garden productive by harvesting, replanting, and rotating crops throughout the season
Please bring your own container(s) - buckets, storage bins, flexi tubs, or old drawers all welcome. We will show you how to safely repurpose them.

Charlotte uses an overhead camera projected onto a 55 inch TV for easy step by step instruction.

This workshop is for intermediate to advanced watercolour painters.

Bring your own watercolour paints, palette, brushes, and four Quarter sheets or four A3 sheets each of good quality 100% cotton 300gsm watercolour cold pressed or hot pressed paper.

One hour lunch - bring a packed lunch to have in our historic home or explore the local cafes in Te Aro.

- Have a basic understanding of the Māori spiritual and natural worlds (mana atua, mana whenua), and our important connections to them
- Identify the sounds of Māori letters and pronounce letter combinations using correct intonation and stress patterns
- Confidently greet people, introduce yourself and communicate basic personal information in an informal context
- Identify and respond to phrases in the classroom including basic commands/instructions

description:
The Art of Mending, This class is cared for by the whimsical Aisha, a multidisciplinary artist with a passion for empowering the mending process. Each month on Wednesday evenings Aisha will introduce us to a different technique for reviving our beloved textile pieces. If you're like us and have a box of clothing in need of repairs that never seems to empty... this is the club for you. With three events a month we'll inspire each other to creatively care for those pieces we love! This club is also perfect for anyone who loves learning new skills. Techniques we'll cover are lino printing, patching, darning, felting, embroidery, beading, sashiko, fabric painting and more! All materials and tools are supplied at each class - but you are welcome to bring your own and we highly encourage bringing a textile item (or many!) to fix up.
In August we're lino printing!
Class 01: 13th August
In this class we'll get an introduction to lino printing on fabric and best practice for using this process to cover stains. Pre cut designs and all other tools are supplied. Please bring either clothing you would like to print on or some fabric scrap to make lino printed patches!
Class 02: 20th August
At this class Aisha will take us through the process of designing and cutting our own lino to print with! You're welcome to keep going with the pre cut designs as well. Lino and carving tools will be supplied.
Class 03: 27th August
This class will be open to what you want to work on! Bring in larger project items, print with the lino cuts you made in the previous week, or cut some fresh ones!

description:
The Art of Mending, When it comes to the clothes we love, every rip, stain, and imperfection is an invitation to exercise agency, expression, and an opportunity to show the garment how much we appreciate it.
This class is cared for by the whimsical Aisha, a multidisciplinary artist with a passion for empowering the mending process. Each month on Wednesday evenings Aisha will introduce us to a different technique for reviving our beloved textile pieces. If you're like us and have a box of clothing in need of repairs that never seems to empty... this is the club for you. With three events a month we'll inspire each other to creatively care for those pieces we love! This club is also perfect for anyone who loves learning new skills. Techniques we'll cover are lino printing, patching, darning, felting, embroidery, beading, sashiko, fabric painting and more! All materials and tools are supplied at each class - but you are welcome to bring your own. We highly encourage bringing those clothes or other textile items that need some love and repair.
There is no need to attend every class. We can catch you up on the skill at which ever class you choose to join us at. There are single class tickets or monthly sign ups available. Both of these have variable pricing options, unwaged/student, waged, and generous. Please choose whichever option feels right for you and your circumstances!
In August we are Lino Printing!
Class 02: 20th August
At this class Aisha will take us through the process of designing and cutting our own lino to print with! You're welcome to keep going with the pre cut designs as well. Lino and carving tools will be supplied.
Class 03: 27th August
This class will be open to what you want to work on! Bring in larger project items, print with the lino cuts you made in the previous week, or cut some fresh ones!
In September we are patching!
Class 01: 10th September
Aisha will take us through the process of sewing on patches. Patches that we printed in the August classes will be available for this. You're welcome to bring your own patches as well. Please bring something that needs a patch up or a little bit of decoration.
Class 02: 17th September
At this class we will learn how to appliqué, the process of using scrap fabric to make decorative patches. This is a great way to elevate a rip or stain with some visible mending.
Class 03: 24th September
At this last class of the month we'll be open for all the patching needs. Hang out and finish projects we've started or mend some extra items.
Be sure to check our website or here for updates about techniques coming up in the following months.

description:
Art and AI: Brit Bunkley in Conversation with Megan Dunn, Artist and filmmaker Brit Bunkley discusses the pragmatics and politics of making art with AI. Join us for a discussion in the Gallery, with insights into the making of his latest work Archive, commissioned for Messengers.
--
Brit Bunkley is a New Zealand-based artist and videographer whose practice spans sculpture, installation, and digital media. A recipient of the US National Endowment for the Arts fellowship, two NY state grants, and the Rome Prize Fellowship, his work explores the intersection of physical and virtual spaces, often blending surreal imagery with themes of history, politics, and environmental concerns. He has exhibited at the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa and internationally at Rencontres Internationales Paris/Berlin, FILE São Paulo (including 2025), and the Athens Digital Arts Festival. Recent exhibitions include Visions in the Nunnery, London (2022), Cybersculpture 2024 at Collège des Bernardins, Paris, and The Torrance Art Museum, LA (2025). In 2024, he won Best Art | Experimental Video/Film at the New York City Independent Film Festival. His work continues to evolve, embracing new technologies and alternative methodologies to challenge perceptions of reality and imagination.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Author Talk: Oceans Between Us ed. by Sereana Naepi, We're delighted to have Sereana Naepi in the shop to talk about Oceans Between Us: Pacific Peoples & Racism in Aotearoa, which she edited and was published by Auckland University Press.
Oceans Between Us is both a testimony and a call to action. It documents the struggles of Pacific peoples and envisions a world beyond now. A rallying cry for justice, a demand for equity and a catalyst for change, this book is not about survival alone – it’s about thriving.
All welcome!
label: Community & Culture

description:
Bailamos Bachata! Latin Dance Party (with free lesson), Please note: the event is free but it can only continue if we support the Southern Cross by buying food or drinks

Wellington’s favourite monthly Bachata Latin dance party

Join us for an awesome mix of bachata, focusing on the best sensual tracks and remixes, along with salsa and a smattering of kizomba and zouk. We welcome everyone, from the absolute beginner to the most experienced dancer. We’re all about the joy of social dancing together.
And what makes a free party with great people even better? A free beginners’ bachata lesson with some of Wellington‘s best Latin dance teachers. If you’ve never danced bachata, Latin dance or even any other dance style before then this is the perfect lesson for you. We will have you dancing like a pro in no time!
Bailamos Bachata is hosted free of charge by the Southern Cross. They love the atmosphere we bring but we also need to support them in return. We’re asking everyone attending to purchase soft drinks, food or alcohol from the bar. It’s vital we show our gratitude.
1800-1830 social
1830-1900 free lesson
1900-2100 social
Q&A
Q. What is bachata?
A. Bachata is a popular and fun Latin couples dance. It started in the Dominican Republic, then travelled to Europe and the rest of the world. It now includes a wide range of music styles and dance influences and is still changing and evolving.
Q. I haven’t danced before, is that a problem?
A. Not at all! That’s exactly what the lesson is for – everyone has to start somewhere and we’re a very welcoming crowd for beginners.
Q. Is bachata a difficult dance to learn?
A. Its origins as a party/community dance mean the basics can be learnt quite quickly, so you’ll be enjoying yourself in no time.
Q. Who are the capital bachata collective?
A. We are the combined Wellington dance schools and people teaching bachata and we really want to share this dance with everyone. We love bachata, we love our community and we want to share it with you
￼

description: Care, anarchy, and mutual aid,  Care, anarchy, and mutual aid: responses to crisis and disaster by the community, for the community  (a community proposed event) We will walk through tangible examples from Monica's experiences of mutual aid organizing for different crisis contexts in Chicago (USA), dispelling disaster myths, what anarchist approaches to community care look like, and brainstorming around what we can do together around what we face as community members in Te Whanganui-a-Tara.  Zines and kai will be shared.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Carnival of Chaos, Myth, chaos, murder, alchemy, mystery, and devils are afoot in this four-night festival featuring six short retellings of classic works with strange new twists! We invite you to THEA 303’s ‘Carnival of Chaos’ in Studio 77, premiering hybrid works from the House of Echoes (1 & 3 October): The Odyssey, Medea and The Devil is a Lover, and the House of Secrets (2 & 4 October): Rope, The Taming of the Shrew  and  God’s Gift.

Each adaptation has been directed, designed, produced, choreographed and managed by the students.

House of Echoes (Season A): Performs on the 1st and the 3rd of October

The Odyssey – An adaptation of Homer’s The Odyssey
Odysseus just wants to get home to his true love, but the journey isn’t exactly smooth. The streets after 2 a.m. and too many beers are alive with obstacles; cops are grumpy, goth girls are tempting, and the help of the Gods is nowhere to be found. Meanwhile, back home, a dangerous polycule is getting cozy with his Penelope…

Medea – An adaptation of Euripides’ Medea
Medea lives her perfect 1950s white picket fence dream! When her husband starts taking new pills “Conservatol, the wonder drug for traditional love” she learns that traditional love means different to what she thought. Betrayal, hurt, and anger push her to the edge making her act in ways she never thought she would. “Heaven has no rage like love to hatred turned, nor Hell a fury like a woman scorned.”

The Devil is a Lover – An adaptation of William Shakespeare’s Love Labours Lost and Ben Johnson’s The Devil is an Ass
Satan and two devils, Beelzebub and Pug, make a pact to travel to a 1920s speakeasy on Earth and abstain from corruption for 3 years. As the narrative combines absurdist actions with Shakespearean dialogue, the three devils quickly learn of the difficulties present in avoiding corruption and the effect their devilish meddling has on humanity.

House of Secrets (Season B): Performs on the 2nd and 4th of October

Rope – An adaptation of Patrick Hamilton’s Rope (1929)
Not a whodunnit, but a howdoyahideit? Marion and Melanie are sure they’ve committed the perfect murder by killing their friend Norman and hiding his body in a chest, a chest their select group of friends have been invited over to have a murder mystery games night around. It’s foolproof, until the over analytical Constance comes to play…

The Taming of the Shrew – An adaptation of William Shakespeare’s Taming of the Shrew
In 1970's Aotearoa, sisters Katherina and Bianca find their love lives complicated by their father's order that one may not pursue romance unless the other follows suit. The sudden appearance of a charming factory owner and friend of Bianca's beau could mark a new hope for the two, but will this lead to an ocean of love or does something far more sinister lurk beneath the surface?

God’s Gift – An adaptation of Ben Johnson’s The Alchemist
The Carnival has come to town in 1615 London. Lovewit has gone to see the show, leaving her manor in the hands of Jeremy the Butler, the “Alchemist,” and Dol, a hardworking prostitute. Lovewit’s house becomes a place for schemes, with ample opportunities to take money from foolish men. Will Dol be happy with her split of the money? Or will a surprise visitor shake things up?

Content Forecast: mentions of and implied sexual violence and domestic abuse, mentions of drug use, strobe lighting, violence, coarse language, loud noises, haze, and smoke.

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - 2025 Wellington Heritage Festival: Gallows Tour, Crime, Justice, and the Final Walk.
Delve into the complex history of capital punishment in Wellington with this thought-provoking tour through Karori Cemetery. Gallows shines a light on the people behind the process. Discover their roles in shaping justice, the cases that defined their careers, and the human stories behind a system of ultimate consequence.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day 1 hour before the tour starts by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
This tour is approximately 2 hours long.
This tour contains a number of adult themes and some graphic descriptions so is not suitable for everyone.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions.
While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility.
There is only one toilet which is located by the cemetery office at the main entrance.
If you have purchased tickets for other people can you please pass our tour information on to them as well.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - 2025 Wellington Heritage Festival: Our Fair Ladies (April 2025), Our Fair Ladies Tour
Embark on a captivating journey through the history buried in Karori Cemetery with our tour showcasing the remarkable lives of Wellington's women.
This tour offers a unique opportunity to celebrate the resilience, creativity and empowerment of women at a time when a woman couldn't have a bank account in her own name.  You'll hear the stories of women who had a range of interesting occupations. 
Be inspired by the incredible impact of these women's lives in early Wellington.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day by 9am by email and on our Facebook page.

Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility. Please read the tour descriptions carefully to check that they will be suitable for you.
We will meet before the tour at the Shelter (listed as Historic chapel on the map)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

This tour traverses some of the older parts of the story where historic headstones mark the stories of lives lost too soon: accidents, murder, misadventure and those who fell by their own hand.
This tour contains a number of adult themes and some graphic descriptions so is not suitable for everyone.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.

Delve into the complex history of capital punishment in Wellington with this thought-provoking tour through Karori Cemetery. Gallows shines a light on the people behind the process. description:
Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever, STARTS: 1pm, SUNDAY 5 OCT
In 2004, Georgina Beyer, the first openly transgender Member of Parliament in the world, famously confronted members of Destiny Church during the Enough Is Enough rally on the grounds of Parliament.
Never a bystander, Georgina faced down the bigots, telling them straight, “Your hatred is totally intolerable!” This was just one of many significant moments that shaped the life of the extraordinary Georgina Beyer.
Born in Wellington, Georgina went on to have an unprecedented local, national and international impact through her commitment to equality and her desire to give everyone the opportunity to reach their full potential in society.
Join us for this special 90-minute walking tour as we pay tribute to the late Georgina (1957–2023) by visiting locations around central Wellington that shaped her journey. Along the way, we’ll honour some of her heroes and listen to first-hand archival audio clips that showcase her humour and resilience.
Georgina’s story is defiantly optimistic – confronting hardship and using her lived experience to change the world for the better.
Time/Date: 1pm, Sunday 5 October 2025
Starts: meet outside St Peters Church, 211 Willis Street
Ends: Vivian Street
Duration: 90 minutes
Cost / Bookings: the tour is free but you do need to register here: https://walktoursnz.wordpress.com/book/
Accessibility information: the tour is on flat public footpaths. Tours are limited to approximately 20 walkers.
Image courtesy of the amazing Kym Strathdee

description:
Kapiti Crop Swap PUKERUA BAY, THIS INVITE IS FOR THE PUKERUA BAY SWAP

Everyone is welcome to our CROP SWAP meetings!
1st Saturday of the month – Otaki (1-2pm)
2nd Saturday of the month – Raumati (1-2pm)
3rd Saturday of the month – Pukerua Bay (3-4pm)
4th Saturday of the month – Waikanae (2-3pm)
To be clear, at Crop Swap, we swap more than just crops! We share everything homegrown and homemade: Vegetables, fruits, herbs, plants, seedlings, flowers, seeds, baking, preserves, sauces, jam and all things yummy! You can also bring everything garden and kitchen related like empty containers, tools, labels, planting pots, worm juice, coffee grounds, gardening magazines, cook books, recipes, a SKILL…possibilities are endless.
The key is that this is a cashless event, no koha can offered or accepted.
This is generally how a Crop Swap will run:
3-2.15pm
• People arrive with their crops and put them out on the tables provided.
• You are then free to chat and mingle with your fellow garden enthusiasts, exchange tips, make new friends or just wait until it starts.
3.15-3.45pm
• We conduct a quick briefing outlining the guidelines for swapping.
• If there is not a lot of people, we can listen to anyone who wants to introduce their crop.
• Once everyone has placed their crops we like to do a Karakia to bless the kai. We want to emphasise our values regarding generous giving and mindful taking.
3.45-4pm
• Close out, put away tables and clear the hall.
The meetings will be held regularly on the 2nd Saturday of every month in Raumati and the last Saturday of every month in Waikanae.
Further information:
1. There will be a koha food box for anyone who wants to donate food or seedlings in addition to their swaps. The Crop Swap team will distribute any koha crop and left over crops to local food pantries.
2. If you do not have any crops to swap but need fresh fruit or veges for the next week, you can bring plants, flowers, seedlings, herbs, eggs, preserves, jams, baking, liquid manure, gardening books, magazines, planting containers, sometimes even chooks who need a new home! We want this to be accessible to everyone, especially those who are struggling to put fresh fruit and veges on the table!
label: Community & Culture

description:
Manu Park Site Viewing, Manu Park Site Viewing
Meet us and find out how you can build your dream home in a new subdivision that combines outstanding natural beauty and a real sense of community.
The agent is on-site at the end of Karuhiruhi Street every Sunday between 10.00am - 11.00am.
Since its establishment in 2018, Manu Park has become a highly sought-after community, with Stages One and Two fully sold out. Don’t miss your chance to secure a piece of this paradise in Stage 3, where only 8 sections remain.
Manu Park isn’t just a place to live—it’s a place to belong. Designed with families in mind, it offers a safe and welcoming environment where kids can ride their bikes down quiet streets, explore nature on their doorstep, and grow up knowing their neighbours. Centrally located near Waikanae township it offers expansive open spaces and a strong sense of community; Manu Park is a neighbourhood where friendships flourish and families thrive.
Nestled within protected native bush, Manu Park offers breathtaking surroundings, generously sized sections, and the opportunity to build a home tailored to your vision and lifestyle. Named after the Māori word for bird, it sits beside the renowned Nga Manu Nature Reserve, close to Waikanae’s excellent schools and amenities, just minutes from the beach, and under an hour from Wellington city.
Teaming up with local building companies, Manu Park offers House and Land packages for a seamless home-building experience. Visit Manu Park to explore Design and Build opportunities to create a home that perfectly fits your lifestyle.
Don’t miss this rare opportunity to be part of a vibrant community where nature and modern living come together. Visit manupark.nz to learn more and secure your section today

You may also like the following events from Manu Park - Build your dream:
This Sunday, 7th September, 12:00 am, Manu Park Site Viewing in Waikanae

description:
Miramar Local History Event : Wonderland, Wonderland was Wellington’s first ever amusement park. Based in Miramar, it opened in 1907 and was located near the present-day Wētā Cave. At the time it was one of the biggest amusement parks in the Southern Hemisphere. Its various attractions were originally to be found at the New Zealand International Exhibition of 1906-1907 and were brought to Wellington after that exhibition closed. The park has a fascinating and interesting back story which the panellists will explore.
This very special event will be an unmissable treat for all local history buffs as well as a fabulous journey into Wellington’s and especially Miramar’s past, and features two of Aotearoa’s finest and most acclaimed historical novelists and Wellington City Libraries' own Local History Specialist.
Meet the panel:
Tracy Farr:
Tracy Farr's debut novel The Life and Loves of Lena Gaunt was long­listed for Australia’s Miles Franklin Literary Award, shortlisted for the Barbara Jefferis Award and Western Australian Premier’s Book Awards. Wonderland is her third novel and is set in and during the time of Miramar’s Wonderland.
Philippa Werry:
Multi-award winning historical fiction writer Philippa Werry’s most recent book Iris and me about the travels of Robin Hyde won the Young Adult Fiction Award at the NZ Book Awards for Children and Young Adults. Her numerous other works include award winning fiction, non-fiction, picture books, plays and poetry, with a special emphasis on children and young adults, and a particularly strong focus on Aotearoa / New Zealand stories and history.
And to complete our illustrious panel we have Wellington City Library’s Local History Specialist, Gábor Tóth.

description:
New Zealand Game Developers Conference, This is more than just a conference; it’s a celebration of Aotearoa’s amazing game dev community.
Our theme for this year is The People at the Heart of Games and is inspired by the well-known Māori proverb “He aha te mea nui o te ao? He tangata, he tangata, he tangata” (What is the most important thing in the world? It is people, it is people, it is people), emphasising the human side of game development.
It speaks to the importance of community, collaboration and the people who shape our industry - developers, storytellers, players, and cultural guardians.
We’ll have inspiring talks, engaging workshops, and vibrant panel discussions that highlight voices from all corners of our industry.
Whether you’re a veteran developer, an enthusiastic gamer, or just starting your journey, NZGDC 2025 is the perfect place to forge new friendships, exchange ideas, and ignite your creativity!

description:
Pride In Place: Creating a Community Walk Tour, Join the team from Walk Tours NZ for a free and inspiring presentation on how to create and run your own non-profit community walk tour.

Over the past seven years, Walk Tours NZ has delivered more than 100 community tours around central Wellington, focusing on the city’s rich LGBTQIA+ Rainbow heritage.

This event goes behind the scenes of creating a walk tour and is perfect for anyone passionate about bringing place-based history to light – whether it’s Rainbow histories or a topic of your own choosing.

Hosts Roger Smith and Gareth Watkins will guide you through the key ingredients of a successful non-profit walk tour – including identifying interesting stops, crafting compelling narratives, and being an engaging host – even if you’ve never done it before!

Bring your curiosity, enthusiasm and ideas, and discover why walk tours offer a unique form of living history – and how the experience can build community and connect people. No previous walk tour experience is necessary, and all are welcome.

The Queen Elizabeth II Pukeahu Education Centre (formerly the Home of Compassion Crèche) in Pukeahu Park has limited space, so registration is essential.
Please sign-up here: https://walktours.nz/book

This free community event is part of the Aotearoa Festival of Architecture 2025, organised by Walk Tours NZ in collaboration with the New Zealand Institute of Architects (Wellington Branch).
label: Community & Culture

description:
Pride in Place: creating a community walk tour, Join the team from Walk Tours NZ for a free and inspiring presentation on how to create and run your own non-profit community walk tour.
Over the past seven years, Walk Tours NZ has delivered more than 100 community tours around central Wellington, focusing on the city’s rich LGBTQIA+ Rainbow heritage.
This event goes behind the scenes of creating a walk tour and is perfect for anyone passionate about bringing place-based history to light – whether it’s Rainbow histories or a topic of your own choosing.
Hosts Roger Smith and Gareth Watkins will guide you through the key ingredients of a successful non-profit walk tour – including identifying interesting stops, crafting compelling narratives, and being an engaging host – even if you’ve never done it before!
The presentation will cover both traditional methods of researching and writing, as well as demonstrate some off-the-shelf Artificial Intelligence applications that can help support your storytelling.
Bring your curiosity, enthusiasm and ideas, and discover why walk tours offer a unique form of living history – and how the experience can build community and connect people. No previous walk tour experience is necessary, and all are welcome.
The Queen Elizabeth II Pukeahu Education Centre (formerly the Home of Compassion Crèche) in Pukeahu Park has limited space, so registration is essential.
Please register here: https://walktours.nz/book
This free community event is part of the Aotearoa Festival of Architecture 2025, organised by Walk Tours NZ in collaboration with the New Zealand Institute of Architects (Wellington Branch).

description:
Rheem training in Masterton, We're heading back to Masterton to deliver free local product training.
This season of Rheem Training for Tradies events will provide background knowledge of product updates and new models. We’ll cover operation, installation requirements and clear-up some myths relating to installation practices, and warranty.
Topics covered:
Heat pump water heaters –
Benefits, current range, installation, service and warranty
Gas continuous flow –
New model updates, installation, commissioning, service, fault-finding and warranty
Electric storage cylinders –
Benefits of model types for harsh water areas, installation and warranty
Myth busting facts –
installation and warranty requirements
Boiling water –
Lazer and Zip models explained, live demonstration of Lazer operation, sequence of operation explained to help with fault-finding

description:
Speed Dating for the Neurodivergent, Age groups: 30-42, 43-55

Looking to meet new friends to hang out with, or maybe find love in a comfortable, respectful environment? Join us for a speed dating event designed specifically for autistic adults in Wellington!

This inclusive and sensory-considerate evening is all about meaningful conversations and low-pressure socializing. Whether you’re looking for friendship, romance, or just a fun evening out, this is your chance to connect in a space designed with your needs in mind.

Cost: $39, includes food and first drink

Age groups: 20-35, 35-50

Accessibility and Comfort:
We’re committed to making this event as accessible and welcoming as possible. Sensory-friendly spaces, quiet zones, and fidget-friendly items will be available. There will also be conversation prompts on the table. Let us know any additional accommodations you may need when registering.

Who Can Attend:
All genders and sexualities are welcome to come and mingle and meet others for friendship but the speed dating part of this evening works best for heterosexual people.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Spring Céilí Dance with The Great Beag Céilí Band, Spring has sprung, the days are getting longer, the rain is falling sideways. Must be about time we had another céilí! Join The Great Beag Céilí Band at St Michael’s Hall in Kelburn for a rousing evening of dancing to foot-stomping celtic tunes. Our Autumn céilí sold out so make sure you get your tickets early!
If you’ve never been to a céilí (or ceilidh) before, fear not - céilí dancing is very easy! No fancy moves or any previous experience required: our caller will explain each dance, and we’ll all walk it through a couple of times before adding the music.
This is social dancing so bring all your friends! No need to bring a specific partner - there’ll be lots of friendly people to dance with.
Discounted online tickets are available on Humanitix until midnight on September 26th: $24 / $16 concession
https://events.humanitix.com/beag-ceili-spring-ceili-2025
Some door sales may be available on the day: $30 / $20 concession (cash only)
—
Doors open 7:30pm
Adults and age 10+ welcome. Under 16s accompanied by an adult.
Light refreshments will be available. We recommend bringing a water bottle to grab a quick drink between dances - hydration is key!
This is an alcohol-free event.
Getting here: St Michael’s Hall is located at 81 Upland Road in Kelburn Village, just behind the church.
There is very limited on-street parking in the village. We recommend public transport: the 4, 18, 21, and 22 buses stop regularly right outside coming up from Te Aro or down from Northland and Karori.
Be safe online: Tickets are only available online from the Humanitix event. Do not buy tickets from other sources such as Facebook comments or resale sites - these are always scams. If you can no longer attend, please contact us via Humanitix, our socials, or email to discuss refunds.
Health notice: Céilí dancing is a great way to meet lots of people. If you are feeling unwell then please stay home and rest this time, we will see you at the next one.
label: Community & Culture

description:
THE GRAND KIKI HOUSE OF MARAMA BALL, The Trailblazing Kiki House of Marama present THE GRAND KIKI HOUSE OF MARAMA BALL 🌙
Proudly supported by OVĀ Collective and Te Papa Tongarewa.
The Grand Kiki House of Marama Ball will celebrate five years of the Kiki House of Marama excellence and the legacy of the growing Wellington Ballroom scene.
Join us for a night of high-energy performances and out-of-this-world fashion as walkers compete for trophies and prizes in a display of Black and Brown queer and trans joy, liberation, and Ballroom* artistry.
With a fabulous line-up of Categories, Judges, Commentators and DJ, including major local and international Ballroom figures, we invite you to wear your best outfits and prepare to finger snap ✨ 🤏 dance 💃 and cheer 🥳 the night away at Te Papa Tongarewa on Sat 4th Oct.
Ballroom Community Walkers & Spectators Ticket Access
Contact our House account on Instagram @houseofmarama or your local Ballroom leaders for the access codes to Ballroom Community Spectators & Walkers tickets.
There is a discount code for Fem Queens FREE access for FQ who are not walking/competing, please contact us or your local leaders for the discount code.
Categories & Themes
Virgin Vogue - A Marama Storm (Treasure)
Bizarre - Nocturnal Creatures of Folklore
Realness (FQ, TM and BQ) - Date Night Under the Moonlight
Hands Performance - Memoirs from Mother Marama
Body (Slim, Thicc and Luscious) - Heavenly Bodies
Butch Queen Vogue Fem - A Marama Storm (Pirates)
Face (FF, MF and GNC) - Beauty of the Blood Moon
OTA Best Dressed - Once in a Blue Moon
Commentator vs. Commentator - Echoes of the Moon
Femme Queen Performance - A Marama Storm (Mermaids)
OTA Runway - The Phases of Marama
House of the Night (no theme)
Judges, Commentators & DJ announcement coming soon...
Please do not hesitate to contact us via houseofmarama@gmail.com or on all social media @houseofmarama for any questions or concerns.
⎯
Ballroom* is a safe space created in the 1960's, forged by the Black, Latinx and queer Americans in protest against the racism and queerphobia that they faced from the non-queer community and white queer community. It is a space held to protect trans womxn of colour, so as guests and participants within this culture it is imperative that we all do our best to respect and honour this sacred space. Homophobia, Transphobia, and any discriminatory language and/or beliefs will not be tolerated. Remember to check your privilege at the door.
To learn more about the culture of Underground Ballroom check out this link: https://artsandculture.google.com/project/ballroom. Be sure to check out the growing Wellington Ballroom scene and community by following @houseofmarama and @ova_collective on Instagram.
label: Community & Culture

description:

Join us for an inspiring evening in the heart of Aotearoa New Zealand’s much-loved national museum. Feast your eyes and discover new favourites in Toi Art – the home of the National Art Collection. Enjoy handcrafted cocktails, then savour an exquisite three-course dinner paired with premium local wines. Bid on exclusive experiences and luxury items in our live charity auction, thanks to Webb’s. Celebrate the evening with performances from acclaimed local musicians, including Ainslie Allen and Lisa Tomlins.

All proceeds from the event support exhibitions, research, and education programmes, ensuring Te Papa continues to thrive for generations to come.

description:
Te Papa Foundation Gala, Wellington’s premier fundraising event, the Te Papa Foundation Gala brings together Aotearoa New Zealand’s leading supporters of arts and culture for one spectacular night in the museum.
Enjoy handcrafted cocktails, discover new favourites in the Toi Art galleries, savour an exquisite three-course dinner paired with premium local wines, bid in our live charity auction, and then dance to live performances from acclaimed local musicians.
Thanks to Webb’s, the Gala features a special live auction of once-in-a-lifetime experiences, including Sake & sushi with Dick Frizzell, a stunning carving by Tim Steel (Ngāi Tahu), and luxury escapes.
Tickets cost $3,000 for a table of ten, or $300 per person.
All proceeds from the Gala supports Te Papa’s work across art, culture, history, science, and nature, ensuring that our much-loved national museum continues to thrive for generations to come.
Can’t make it? Our digital auction will be hosted by Webb’s from 28 August until 10 September. More information at tepapa.nz/gala.

description:
Our Beloved Indigenous Vegetation - Guided Walk, In this approximately one-hour downhill walk we will obtain a perspective on several native plants from the ubiquitous, such as our well-known cabbage tree, kōwhai and podocarps, to lesser-knowns such as shrubby toroaro/mingimingi, Bartlett's rātā, Three Kings kaikōmako and Three Kings vine/akapukaea. We will also discuss the phenomenon of species radiation exemplified by Hebe and Kauri.
Meet at the Cable Car Entrance Lookout, Upland Road, Kelburn.
Cost: $5 (cash only, please). or free for Friends.
This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run twice monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.
Join the Friends for only $30 a year and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefits.

description:
Ruamahanga Farm learning day, At this Toru Trail, we are delighted and look forward to a day of planting, learning, connecting and creating at the Ruamahanga farm.
Three kilometers west of Martinborough, Ruamahanga Farm Foundation are restoring an oxbow wetland and the riperian edge of the Ruamanhanga river.
Our hosts: Jane Riddiford and Rod Sugden will be demontrating to us how this restoration work provides a platform for Te Reo o te Wai, and how the arts and conservation programme for local primary children is filling a need for experiential learning.
Children and young people learn about ecology, practice hands-on conservation and find their own ways to ceatively expressing what it means for them to connect to special places withing the Wairarapa Moana.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day, Once a year, we throw open the gates and invite you behind the scenes at Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush. It’s your chance to explore the only public botanic garden in Aotearoa dedicated solely to native plants. Discover the people, plants, and projects that make it special.

Meet our team, chat with partner organisations, join an activity, and find out how we’re working together to protect and restore our natural environment. Whether you’ve never been to Ōtari before or it’s been a while, come along, get curious, and reconnect with nature!

On the day:

10 am-2 pm: Tū Mātau Ora – Taonga Tākaro (Traditional Māori games) on the lawn

10 am-2 pm: Conservation community partner stalls

10:30 am-2 pm: Plant sale – native plants grown right here in the Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush Trust Nursery

10:30 am, 11:30 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Behind-the-scenes tours with Ōtari staff (sign up on the day)

10:30 am -12:30 pm: Rongoā workshop – learn about traditional Māori plant uses. Free registration opens soon

10:30 am, 11:45 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Author talks – Ruth Paul, Phil Sirvid, Leon Perrie, and Michael Szabo discuss their recent books

11 am: Lions Ōtari Plant Conservation Laboratory staff show and tell – see our orchid conservation work up close

11 am & 1 pm: String Bean Puppets – two shows: Once in a Full Moon (Kiwi adventures) and Tree Friends (weed-busting fun)
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Box of Birds, Hailed as "the cutest little show in Aotearoa" (Hamilton Arts Festival 2024), award-winning theatre company Birdlife Productions have created this gorgeous theatre show designed especially for ages 4 to 9 years, Including exquisite puppetry, live interactive songs, projection and the teaching of a waiata, this work reflects our transformative connection to nature. Peter is reluctant to stay with nanna in the school holidays because she lives in the country and doesn't have a TV but Nanna finds ways to engage Peter in her love of the forest, especially the precious manu, when they build a nesting box for Ruru together. Peter is excited to see if Ruru will make her home in the box, waiting patiently while many other birds arrive to check out the box first! And after all that waiting, Nanna takes Peter on an exciting night time forest walk to find Ruru - in the dark! The bird characters are all familiar New Zealand locals, such as piwakawaka, kereru, tui and ruru, and the story highlights the importance of supporting them and the different needs they may have. Teachers and Parents have been ecstatic about this show and hundreds of New Zealand children have been transfixed by it.
As quoted by Theatreview: “This is truly a New Zealand show for New Zealand children and all those young-at-heart”.

description:

You can show your support by creating your own BOTY2025 campaign merch! Whether it’s a “Kiwi 4 Me” flag, “Vote Kākā” bunting, or “Hihi for BOTY” stickers, get the word out there and support your favourite manu (bird).

Local artists Margaret Tolland and Tayla Hartemink will supply the materials for these free events and guide tamariki (kids) in creating their very own campaign merch to take home. You can even bring your own shirt, cap, or other cloth item to decorate! All ages are welcome.

Zealandia Te Māra a Tāne is delighted to be the Campaign Manager for the kiwi in the 2025 Bird of the Year competition. Spot prizes are up for grabs for the best kiwi merch!
label: Family Friendly

description:
Cèilidh Dance Fundraiser for WMC, Get your dancing shoes on and bring the kids! The Wellington Music Centre invites you to join a vibrant and lively evening of traditional Scottish and Irish social dancing, featuring the sensational VicFolk band! This beginner-friendly, all-ages partner dancing event is designed to bring families and the community together for a night of fun, music, and connection, all while supporting the Wellington Music Centre.

Details

12th September 2025
6 - 9pm
St Patrick's Hall, 17 Rongotai Road, Kilbirnie
Ages 0-99
Tickets:
https://www.wellingtonmusiccentre.org.nz/.../wmc-ceili-dance
Activities
Traditional Partner Dancing: Learn and enjoy traditional Scottish and Irish dances, led by the VicFolk caller*, making it perfect for beginners and families.
Live Music: Dance the night away to the energetic and foot-stomping tunes provided by the sensational VicFolk band.
Raffle: Grab a ticket to our raffle for a chance to win fantastic prizes!
Silent Auction: Bid on unique items and experiences donated by local businesses in our silent auction, including tickets to Roxy cinema, and a family pass to Wēta Workshop, with all proceeds supporting the Wellington Music Centre.
Food and Drinks: Food and beverages are available for purchase throughout the evening. This is an alcohol-free event.
*the caller leads the band and calls out instructions for the dancers, usually with a good sense of humour! They make sure everyone is having a great time, especially those who have never attended a cèilidh dance before.

Supporting Wellington Music Centre:
A cèilidh is about more than dancing, it’s a place to enjoy time with your family and connect as a community. At Wellington Music Centre, we are passionate about bringing joyful and affordable musical experiences to kids and families in South and East Wellington. Proceeds from the event will directly benefit the Wellington Music Centre, helping to fund our great programmes, including the Peninsula Family Choir, the Miramar Kids Choir, the Wellington Music Centre Orchestra, our foundational music courses: Music Explorers and the Ukulele Ensemble, and our free twice-a-year community events.
You can read more about the Wellington Music Centre and our fantastic programmes on our website:
https://www.wellingtonmusiccentre.org.nz/
label: Family Friendly

description:
Daffodil Express 2025, Carterton’s Daffodil Festival in the early Spring creates a great day out for the whole family. Why not travel there in style by a heritage train, let Steam Incorporated take the stress out of travel as you take the train to the Wairarapa. This year, our train has reduced capacity, so be sure to book in quickly!
Hauled by our heritage locomotives, take a glimpse into the bygone era of train travel as we clear the rush of Wellington, racing through the suburbs of Petone, Lower Hutt & Upper Hutt. After picking up the last of our passengers at Upper Hutt, we will race through the 8.8km long Rimutaka tunnel. This tunnel remains the longest in New Zealand with scheduled passenger trains, and has just been subjected to a full track relay for the first time since it was opened in 1955.
Passing through Featherston, we head east and navigate the rolling hills towards Carterton.
Arriving into Carterton, you'll have a few hours to disembark and go and explore Carterton's annual Daffodil Festival , before jumping on the train for the return journey home.
The Daffodil Fields and Festival
Located in the heart of the Wairarapa, Carterton’s popular Daffodil Festival offers an abundance of activities ranging from the famous Daffodil picking at Middlerun Farm, markets along High and Holloway Streets, the Big Wai Art sale in the events Centre, live music, and loads more family fun.
Shuttle buses will run from the town centre to the daffodil fields. There will be a lot of people for these buses, so please be patient. The bus transfer is free.
Here you can pick your own daffodils for $5 (Cash Preferred) that is a fundraiser for Wellington Free Ambulance and Whānau Āwhina Plunket, Wairarapa region. While stocks last!
The fields are not suitable for walkers or wheelchairs due to uneven grounds.
Prior booking is essential, this is an annual sell out event!
Fares
Adult (13+) - $125
Child (2-12yrs) - $90
Infant - Free
For more information & tickets, head to https://steaminc.org.nz/book-train-trip/daffodil-express/
label: Family Friendly

description:
Kids Market - Pop-up Parlour 2025, Kids Market - Pop-up Parlour 2025
Come along and support our young entrepreneurs!

TAKING REGISTRATIONS NOW!!
https://tinyurl.com/yc6myufk

The Kids Market is part of the Pukerua Bay Hub Pop-up Parlour. It is a great opportunity for children up to 16 years of age to show their entrepreneurial spirit and sell their own handmade crafts, baking, good quality used toys, clothes, books etc.

Customers, bring your cash on the day.

Event details
• What - Trading for 2hr and 2hrs of setup/packdown
• When - 12 – 3pm Sunday 14th September 2025
Set up from 10.30pm. Trading 12-3pm. Pack-up to be complete by 4pm.
• Where - St Marks, 98 Rawhiti Road, Porirua, 5026 (opposite the school)
• Cost - koha per table, collected on the day

• What to bring?
A table will be provided to each stall, we recommend you bring a tablecloth. You must bring your own float as there is no access to ATM, eftpos, or power at the stalls. Please no free items as this may affect other children’s sales.

Stalls are limited to two people each and a supervising parent must be onsite at all times.

LIMITED SPACES AVAILABLE.

For more information email
____________________________________
WHAT IS THE POP-UP PARLOUR?
A chance to create and connect in our pop-up community space. From 1-30 September we've got a jam-packed schedule with 65+ events for kids, families, rangatahi and adults to learn, hang out and have fun.

Check out all the free/koha events too -
https://www.pkbhub.org.nz/whatson

Waiho i te toipoto, kaua i te toi roa –
Let us keep close together, not far apart.

description:
Kiwis Big Hararei, Written by Catriona Tipene & Ryan Cundy
Produced by Horse With No Name with GRIDLEY by Victoria
Directed by Catriona Tipene

From the Land of the Long White Cloud to the Land Down Under!

Kiwi is going on his first big holiday from Aotearoa across to the golden shores of Brisbane. He’s got his backpack, a pocket full of worms, and a head full of dreams. The most exciting thing of all is that he might even get to go on a rollercoaster! With his Mum, Kiwi navigates air travel, hotels and conversations with marsupials as his world stretches from the home he knows, to the world over the horizon.

A tale that celebrates the connection between our two countries, featuring stunning costume designs by GRIDLEY by Victoria and fresh waiata by NZ singer-songwriter Benny Tipene. Brought to the stage by the multi-award winning companies Horse With No Name and GRIDLEY by Victoria, Kiwi’s Big Hararei is a story about spreading your wings and flying into the unknown.

Acclaim for Trees, Bees and Me (2024):

“I don’t even know where to start in telling you how absolutely captivating, magical and real this show is.” Tania Du Toit, Regional News

“every costume adds such a beautiful connection between the characters while the colours each beautifully blend so well together.” Brie Keatley, Art Murmurs

Acclaim for Land of the Long Long Drive (2023):

“Horse With No Name have come up with one of the best children’s theatre shows that Wellington has seen in quite some time.” Deborah Rea, Theatreview

Tuesday 23 September 2025 to Saturday 4 October 2025
Tues – Sat 10.00am and 11.30am
Meet the cast: Wednesday 24th September 11.30am and Wednesday 1st October 11.30am
Circa Two
$20 per person
$70 family pass (4 tickets)
label: Family Friendly

description:
SOLD OUT Fairy Potion Garden: An Enchanted Workshop, SOLD OUT Fairy Potion Garden: An Enchanted Workshop
Please join the waitlist for free, and we’ll be in touch if another session is added or if there are any cancellations.

About this Event

Please join the waitlist, and we’ll be in touch if another session is added or if there are any cancellations.
Joining the waitlist is FREE. The $35 shown is the ticket price if more spots become available.
Be sure to check out our other event listings while you’re here too!

SOLD OUT- Fairy Potion Garden: An Enchanted Workshop (1.5 hours)
Step into the enchanted fairy grove for a magical potion-making adventure! Led by a whimsical fairy guide, this hands-on workshop invites young potion crafters (ages 5+) to mix glittery brews, stir up flowery scents, and create their own take-home fairy potions. 🧚‍♀️✨
This 1.5-hour experience is full of sparkly fun, gentle storytelling and a sprinkle of mischief — with fizzy surprises, sweet smells, and lots of giggles.
Includes: 🌸 Potion making with a fairy host 🌼 Take-home fairy potion bottle 🧚‍♀️ Enchanting stories and magical games ✨ Perfect for kids aged 5 and up
A fluttery, fun-filled time for every little fairy and forest friend! 🌿💫

Please note that we are not registered childcare providers, which means an adult responsible for each child must remain on the premises. The venue is also a café restaurant with other areas where parents can chill while the workshop is running.



Also check out other Workshops in Wellington, Kids events & activities in Wellington, Trips & Adventurous Activities in Wellington.

description:
Spring Floral Display Accessible Self-Drive Tour, Gather your friends, whānau, or neighbours who might find it tricky to access the gardens, and enjoy a relaxing, self-guided drive through a spectacular spring floral display at Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā.

Simply drive along the one-way route past the Display Garden and soak in the colours of tulips, forget-me-nots, dianthus, primulas, chrysanthemums, daffodils, and more.

How it works:
- No registration needed — just turn up and enter through the Glenmore Street gates.
- Follow the designated one-way route through the gardens, keeping within your vehicle at all times.
- Exit through the West/White Gate to return to Glenmore Street.
- Feel free to enjoy the route as many times as you like during opening hours.

Please note:
- Drive slowly (maximum 10 km/h), and watch carefully for pedestrians, especially children.
- Stay in your vehicle for the entire tour to keep everyone safe and comfortable.
- Follow all signage and do not turn around within the garden grounds.

This event is self-guided and unstaffed. If you need assistance during your visit, please call 04 499 1400.
For enquiries, email treehouse@wcc.govt.nz or call 04 499 1400.
label: Family Friendly

description:
Take A Kid Tramping - Maketawa Hut Overnight, Take A Kid Tramping - Maketawa Hut Overnight
Family tramping.

Take a Kid Tramping Trip for our kids with extra stamina and ability to carry an overnight pack, this one has a lot of climbing. We will head up the translator track from North Egmont, turn off and follow the ridge down to the hut. The next day we will return via the Makatawa track down through the bush and across a few streams.

All participants must be equipped for tramping in alpine conditions. Overnight tramping equipment required.

Children must be accompanied by a parent or caregiver approved by their guardian.
Shared transport costs apply, unless own transport is provided.
$10 per adult passenger, kids or own car free + hut fee.
Hut Tickets or annual pass required.

If interested, please register by Thursday 11 September:
Jo-anne Mowat |

Also check out other Kids events & activities in Wellington, Trips & Adventurous Activities in Wellington.

As hōtoke draws to a close, we will be exploring the new Te Whare Tapere, or house of entertainment, in the art studio in Toi Art. Follow prompts to find seasonal stories in our exhibitions and make shadow plays using puppets.

description:
The Wellington Brick Show 2025 (LEGO®), The Wellington Brick Show 2025 (LEGO®)
Wellington's largest display of LEGO® builds is back — and its bigger than ever!

This year, over 150 passionate exhibitors from across the country are coming together to showcase their newest, most mind-blowing LEGO® creations at the Wellington Brick Show 2025. From towering cities to pop culture tributes, from amazing spaceships to fanciful unicorns, we have something to inspire and amaze LEGO® fans of all ages.

When:
Saturday 13th and Sunday 14th September

Where:
Walter Nash Centre in Lower Hutt.

How much:
Adults $10 | Children $7 | Family ticket $28
Door sales will also be available.

More information on www.well-lug.nz/upcoming-events

Low sensory admission:
Wellington Brick Show 2025 has a low sensory hour on Sunday 14th September 9-10am, before the doors open to the public. Low sensory hour tickets are intentionally limited - if you are interested in purchasing, please contact

------------------------------------

The Wellington Brick Show is proudly brought to you by Well-LUG - Wellington LEGO® User Group. We are a group of LEGO® fans of all ages from across the lower half of the North Island. New members are always welcome. Find out more about us at www.well-lug.nz

description:
Whānau Day!, Kick off the school holidays with a bang!
Join us for a fun-filled family day inspired by our exhibition Me: Artists Paint Themselves.
Get creative with hands-on activities like collage, painting, and drawing as we explore poses, emotions, and colour. You’ll get to make your own unique artwork to take home!
And don’t miss the FREE face painting (10am-12pm) – what or who could you become!?
Free, drop-in. Limited capacity, first come first served!
Access information: The New Zealand Portrait Gallery is an accessible venue, all on one level. There is an accessible wharepaku (toilet) at the back of the venue. The gallery has automatic sliding doors and glass doors that can be pushed or pulled to enter. We have a wheelchair available for use within the gallery, and there is low stool seating throughout. You can find more accessibility information here. If you have any questions regarding accessibility or if there is something we could do to make your visit easier, please get in touch.

description:
Whānau Sculpture with Clay - Creative Arts Holiday Programme, Children and their caregivers are invited to learn how to sculpt with clay!

Each term, Christine brings a different project for the class to work on and in this workshop you will be creating dinosaurs!

Our popular whānau workshops are designed to allow tamariki and their caregivers to work on their own projects side-by-side and learn basic hand-building techniques from experienced ceramicist Christine Winbush.

The pieces will be fired once, (bisqued) and can be decorated with paint at home.

Recommended age for children are 6 and up. The booking is for one child and one adult and an additional child can be added for only $29.

This workshop is part of Inverlochy Art School's September School Holiday Programme. For more teen & tween workshops including photography, jewellery making, animation and sewing head to the 'Tamariki and Teens' section of our website.

description:
Great Sounds Great Festival 2025, Eyegum Music Collective presents GREAT SOUNDS GREAT, a multi-venue music and arts festival taking over Pōneke's Cuba Street precinct for one night only on Saturday 6 September 2025. Showcasing 40 of Aotearoa's best artists across 10 neighbouring venues, this is one big party you shouldn't miss.

Eyegum has worked hard to curate a programme that is sure to offer something for everyone, from first time gig-goers to seasoned live music obsessives. The eclectic lineup includes perennial indie maestros The Bats, capital hometown heroes The Phoenix Foundation, hip hop superstar JessB, troubadour-turned-party starter Anthonie Tonnon, captivating genre-bender Reb Fountain, the incredible local-by-way-of-Naarm Jen Cloher, plus a selection of up-and-coming artists handpicked from Eyegum's Free Wednesday weekly showcase series, and everything in between. There will also be plenty more to be announced soon.

Excitingly for 2025, we will be adding three new venues: St Peter's on Willis, Flying Nun Records and 13 Garrett Street (sponsored by Radio Active), as well as a travelling electronic stage curated by Tonic Collective. This means more artists and music to experience in a variety of special and unique spaces throughout the night.

Ticket holders will receive a wristband that will give them access to each of the participating venues throughout the event. Information on how to pick up wristbands will be provided to ticket holders closer to the time.

Tickets are on sale now at eyegum.co.nz/great-sounds-great

When: from 4pm Saturday 6 September 2025
Where: San Fran, Meow, Valhalla, Rogue & Vagabond, Bedlam & Squalor, Hotel Bristol (2 stages), St Peter's on Willis, Flying Nun Records, 13 Garrett St

Who: The lineup will include Anthonie Tonnon, Baby Zionov, Bad Taste, BADTAB, Baeoli, Bathysphere, The Bats, By A Damn Sight, Cindy, Eveline Breaker, Goya, Half/Angel, Hans Pucket, Iris Little, Jazmine Mary, Jen Cloher, JessB, JHL, Jim Nothing, Jordan Hamel, Leah Dodd, LEAO, Louisa Nicklin, The Phoenix Foundation, Reb Fountain, Rebecca Hawkes, Shayne P Carter (solo), Sig Wilder & Friends, Sofia Machray, Space Bats, Attack!, The Spectre Collective: live-scored cinema, Star Time, plus more artists to be announced soon.

description:
Film screening: GAGA, Gaga《哈勇家》(2022)
Directed by Laha Mebow 112 mins, Mandarin/Atayal/Taiwanese, English subtitles
Among the Atayal indigenous people of Taiwan, gaga is the traditional law and custom, the way of living with the land and organising society, the source of values. When Hayung, the patriarch of an Atayal family, and the senior knowledge-keeper, dies, his oldest son Payang decides to run for election as head of the local district. The film Gaga follows this election, in its raw democratic, and occasionally corrupt, form and the ways – sometimes serious, sometimes hilarious – that it affects the extended family. A groundbreaking film, Gaga is mostly in Atayal language and presents the life and social interactions of these contemporary indigenous Taiwanese people unsentimentally, with humour, with compassion, and with the sharp eye of a brilliant film-maker.
Gaga won Best Director and Best Supporting Actress at the 59th Taipei Golden Horse Film Festival in 2022. Beyond Taiwan, it won the Best Director at the 2022 Singapore International Film Festival - Asian Feature Competition and has been screened at film festivals in Hawaii, Los Angeles, Melbourne, Auckland and New York.
Q&A with Film Director Laha Mebow
We are delighted that Film Director Laha Mebow, Taiwan's first indigenous female director, will be attending the screening and take part in Q&A afterwards.
Laha Mebow is the first female director from Taiwan to win Best Director at the Golden Horse Awards, the most prestigious film award in the Chinese-speaking world. An Indigenous filmmaker of the Tayal people, she is also the first Indigenous woman in Taiwan to direct a narrative feature. Her films explore spiritual inheritance, family trauma, and Indigenous identity through a deeply personal yet cinematic lens.
She has directed three feature films. Finding Sayun (2011) reimagines a colonial-era legend from an Indigenous perspective. Lokah Laqi! (2016), a coming-of-age tale of three Indigenous boys, was selected as Taiwan’s official submission for Best Foreign Language Film at the Academy Awards. Her third feature, Gaga (2022), won Best Film at the Singapore International Film Festival and delves into generational shifts and cultural survival within an Indigenous family.
Laha’s body of work continues to break new ground for Indigenous representation in Asian cinema. Her unique voice bridges traditional storytelling and contemporary filmmaking, making her one of the most important and anticipated directors from Taiwan today.
